alternatives.transcript: Hi there. In this video, we are gonna take a look at the Valgrind program, which is a very important tool that you will use in CS one zero seven to help debug your code. In particular, it is used to find memory leaks in your code. For instance, when you allocated memory during your program and then forgot to free it later when you before the program ends. So I have an example here that I want to show you. So let's take a look at memory leak dot c. And here's the program. It's a very simple program. Basically, we're saying that we have an array size of a thousand. We are creating an array. I know we haven't gotten there yet at the beginning of the school year for, 01/2007 yet, but, instead of, using new like we might in c plus plus we use malloc here to ask for memory from the memory system and to allocate the memory. And in this case, we are allocating an int array, just put the numbers zero through 999 into each one. Then we're gonna randomly grab one to print out. And what we're gonna do is we're gonna end the program without freeing the memory. So in other words, we have a memory leak. Alright. So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna compile this. And to compile this, we're gonna use some compiler commands flags that allow Valgrind to tell us exactly in our program where the memory leak is, which is actually very nice. So what we can do is we can do a dash g and dash o g, and that is an o, uppercase o and not a zero. And then dash s t d equals, gnu 99 for the type of c that we're using and then memory leak dot c and then let's just call the program memory leak. Okay. And it compiled just fine. Remember, GCC can't tell if we have unfreed memory, straight off the bat. So it's, we're gonna just try to run it. If we run this, it'll actually say memory leak and or it'll say, it won't say memory leak, it'll say a number and it won't give us any overt errors. But there is a memory leak and if we run a program called valgrind on it, v a l g r I n d, and we will find this. Now, you have to type Valgrind and then as if you were running the, file. So you type Valgrind and memory leak and watch what happens. Okay. It gives us some things and it runs the code and it actually printed out our answer here and then it gives us a little status at the end here. And what it says is, in use at exit 4,000 bytes. Well, it turns out that, integers are four bytes each and we have 1,000 of them. So this makes sense given what we know about our program. There's 4,000 bytes that are still in use. So if you know a number like that and you happen to know the program and you might be able to that might tell you all you need to know right there. But then it says, look, I made one allocation, I didn't do any freeze and I allocated 4,000 bytes, therefore there are 4,000 bytes left. And then it says, look, you definitely lost 4,000 bytes in one block of memory and it also tells you some other things. So we didn't it didn't sometimes it can't quite tell, so it's possibly lost. And it says that you, you know, that that's the deal. Now, I promised you that we'd be able to tell exactly where the leak was and it says here, rerun with dash dash leak check equals full to see the details of the leaked memory. So if we go and we say valgrind dash dash leak check equals full and then dot slash memory leak, it reruns our code again and it gives us more information. And if there's lots of issues, it will give you lots and lots of information. But in this case, it says, that 4,000 bytes and one box are definitely lost. And what happened was you said malloc in memory leak dot c line nine. And you go, oh, I guess I never freed the memory that I allocated on line nine. So if we look at memoryleak.c, we go down to line nine, we say, oh, yep, look at that, there's our malloc and it looks like we never freed it. So this is a super super important tool to give us enough information to help debug our code, especially when we want to find memory leaks. Now in CS one zero seven, we will expect that your programs don't have any leaks in them or you'll lose points. So how might we fix this? If we go to memoryleak.c and, I actually put this comment in because I knew what I was doing, but if I type free and the pointer which was our int array and then I rerun gcc on it, still compiles just fine. If I run it, it gives me some random number and random array access. And if we run valgrind on it, and let's just run the regular one. I'll clear your screen first. And I'll do that and it says, oh, look, use of exit zero bytes and zero blocks. We had one allocation and one free. Great. We allocated 4,000 bytes. All heap blocks were freed. This is the one that you wanna look for. No leaks are possible. So if you can see that in your code, you know you you know you don't have any memory leaks. So that is how you run Valgrind. Thanks.

Hi there. In this video, we are gonna take a look at the Valgrind program, which is a very important tool that you will use in CS one zero seven to help debug your code. In particular, it is used to find memory leaks in your code. For instance, when you allocated memory during your program and then forgot to free it later when you before the program ends. So I have an example here that I want to show you.

So let's take a look at memory leak dot c. And here's the program. It's a very simple program. Basically, we're saying that we have an array size of a thousand. We are creating an array.

I know we haven't gotten there yet at the beginning of the school year for, 01/2007 yet, but, instead of, using new like we might in c plus plus we use malloc here to ask for memory from the memory system and to allocate the memory. And in this case, we are allocating an int array, just put the numbers zero through 999 into each one. Then we're gonna randomly grab one to print out. And what we're gonna do is we're gonna end the program without freeing the memory. So in other words, we have a memory leak.

Alright. So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna compile this. And to compile this, we're gonna use some compiler commands flags that allow Valgrind to tell us exactly in our program where the memory leak is, which is actually very nice. So what we can do is we can do a dash g and dash o g, and that is an o, uppercase o and not a zero. And then dash s t d equals, gnu 99 for the type of c that we're using and then memory leak dot c and then let's just call the program memory leak.

Okay. And it compiled just fine. Remember, GCC can't tell if we have unfreed memory, straight off the bat. So it's, we're gonna just try to run it. If we run this, it'll actually say memory leak and or it'll say, it won't say memory leak, it'll say a number and it won't give us any overt errors.

But there is a memory leak and if we run a program called valgrind on it, v a l g r I n d, and we will find this. Now, you have to type Valgrind and then as if you were running the, file. So you type Valgrind and memory leak and watch what happens. Okay. It gives us some things and it runs the code and it actually printed out our answer here and then it gives us a little status at the end here.

And what it says is, in use at exit 4,000 bytes. Well, it turns out that, integers are four bytes each and we have 1,000 of them. So this makes sense given what we know about our program. There's 4,000 bytes that are still in use. So if you know a number like that and you happen to know the program and you might be able to that might tell you all you need to know right there.

But then it says, look, I made one allocation, I didn't do any freeze and I allocated 4,000 bytes, therefore there are 4,000 bytes left. And then it says, look, you definitely lost 4,000 bytes in one block of memory and it also tells you some other things. So we didn't it didn't sometimes it can't quite tell, so it's possibly lost. And it says that you, you know, that that's the deal. Now, I promised you that we'd be able to tell exactly where the leak was and it says here, rerun with dash dash leak check equals full to see the details of the leaked memory.

So if we go and we say valgrind dash dash leak check equals full and then dot slash memory leak, it reruns our code again and it gives us more information. And if there's lots of issues, it will give you lots and lots of information. But in this case, it says, that 4,000 bytes and one box are definitely lost. And what happened was you said malloc in memory leak dot c line nine. And you go, oh, I guess I never freed the memory that I allocated on line nine.

So if we look at memoryleak.c, we go down to line nine, we say, oh, yep, look at that, there's our malloc and it looks like we never freed it. So this is a super super important tool to give us enough information to help debug our code, especially when we want to find memory leaks. Now in CS one zero seven, we will expect that your programs don't have any leaks in them or you'll lose points. So how might we fix this? If we go to memoryleak.c and, I actually put this comment in because I knew what I was doing, but if I type free and the pointer which was our int array and then I rerun gcc on it, still compiles just fine.

If I run it, it gives me some random number and random array access. And if we run valgrind on it, and let's just run the regular one. I'll clear your screen first. And I'll do that and it says, oh, look, use of exit zero bytes and zero blocks. We had one allocation and one free.

Great. We allocated 4,000 bytes. All heap blocks were freed. This is the one that you wanna look for. No leaks are possible.

So if you can see that in your code, you know you you know you don't have any memory leaks. So that is how you run Valgrind. Thanks.

sentences.text: Hi there.
In this video, we are gonna take a look at the Valgrind program, which is a very important tool that you will use in CS one zero seven to help debug your code.
In particular, it is used to find memory leaks in your code.
For instance, when you allocated memory during your program and then forgot to free it later when you before the program ends.
So I have an example here that I want to show you.
So let's take a look at memory leak dot c.
And here's the program.
It's a very simple program.
Basically, we're saying that we have an array size of a thousand.
We are creating an array.

I know we haven't gotten there yet at the beginning of the school year for, 01/2007 yet, but, instead of, using new like we might in c plus plus we use malloc here to ask for memory from the memory system and to allocate the memory.
And in this case, we are allocating an int array, just put the numbers zero through 999 into each one.
Then we're gonna randomly grab one to print out.
And what we're gonna do is we're gonna end the program without freeing the memory.
So in other words, we have a memory leak.
Alright.
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna compile this.
And to compile this, we're gonna use some compiler commands flags that allow Valgrind to tell us exactly in our program where the memory leak is, which is actually very nice.
So what we can do is we can do a dash g and dash o g, and that is an o, uppercase o and not a zero.
And then dash s t d equals, gnu 99 for the type of c that we're using and then memory leak dot c and then let's just call the program memory leak.
Okay.
And it compiled just fine.
Remember, GCC can't tell if we have unfreed memory, straight off the bat.
So it's, we're gonna just try to run it.
If we run this, it'll actually say memory leak and or it'll say, it won't say memory leak, it'll say a number and it won't give us any overt errors.
But there is a memory leak and if we run a program called valgrind on it, v a l g r I n d, and we will find this.
Now, you have to type Valgrind and then as if you were running the, file.
So you type Valgrind and memory leak and watch what happens.
Okay.
It gives us some things and it runs the code and it actually printed out our answer here and then it gives us a little status at the end here.
And what it says is, in use at exit 4,000 bytes.
Well, it turns out that, integers are four bytes each and we have 1,000 of them.
So this makes sense given what we know about our program.
There's 4,000 bytes that are still in use.
So if you know a number like that and you happen to know the program and you might be able to that might tell you all you need to know right there.
But then it says, look, I made one allocation, I didn't do any freeze and I allocated 4,000 bytes, therefore there are 4,000 bytes left.
And then it says, look, you definitely lost 4,000 bytes in one block of memory and it also tells you some other things.
So we didn't it didn't sometimes it can't quite tell, so it's possibly lost.
And it says that you, you know, that that's the deal.
Now, I promised you that we'd be able to tell exactly where the leak was and it says here, rerun with dash dash leak check equals full to see the details of the leaked memory.
So if we go and we say valgrind dash dash leak check equals full and then dot slash memory leak, it reruns our code again and it gives us more information.
And if there's lots of issues, it will give you lots and lots of information.
But in this case, it says, that 4,000 bytes and one box are definitely lost.
And what happened was you said malloc in memory leak dot c line nine.
And you go, oh, I guess I never freed the memory that I allocated on line nine.
So if we look at memoryleak.c, we go down to line nine, we say, oh, yep, look at that, there's our malloc and it looks like we never freed it.
So this is a super super important tool to give us enough information to help debug our code, especially when we want to find memory leaks.
Now in CS one zero seven, we will expect that your programs don't have any leaks in them or you'll lose points.
So how might we fix this?

If we go to memoryleak.c and, I actually put this comment in because I knew what I was doing, but if I type free and the pointer which was our int array and then I rerun gcc on it, still compiles just fine.
If I run it, it gives me some random number and random array access.
And if we run valgrind on it, and let's just run the regular one.
I'll clear your screen first.
And I'll do that and it says, oh, look, use of exit zero bytes and zero blocks.
We had one allocation and one free.
Great.
We allocated 4,000 bytes.
All heap blocks were freed.
This is the one that you wanna look for.
No leaks are possible.
So if you can see that in your code, you know you you know you don't have any memory leaks.
So that is how you run Valgrind.
Thanks.
